name: beryllium production | beryllium | Cutoff, U
description:
ecoQuery: https://ecoquery.ecoinvent.org/3.10/cutoff/dataset/24883/documentation

This dataset represents the production of 1 kg beryllium metal in the US. Data come from the publication of Nuss & Eckelman (2014), based on the information provided by Materion Corporation, a company active in the sector of beryllium and related material production. Since it was not possible to disaggregate the production of beryllium metal from subsequent production of semi-finished products (e.g. alloy with >60% Be), the energy requirements used in this assessment include the additional semi-finished products production step. The recycling of Mg and F compounds is not accounted for in this dataset. ;Nuss, P., Eckelman, M.J., 2014. Life cycle assessment of metals: A scientific synthesis. PLoS One 9, 1â€“12. https://doi.org/10.1371/journal.pone.0101298

The activity starts when the beryllium hydroxide enters the process

The activity ends with the production of 1 kg beryllium (metalic form) and semi-finished beryllium containing products.
category: C:Manufacturing/24:Manufacture of basic metals/242:Manufacture of basic precious and other non-ferrous metals

processDocumentation.technologyDescription: Beryllium metal is manufactured by magnesium reduction of anhydrous beryllium fluoride. First of all, beryllium hydroxide is dissolved in ammonium bifluoride solution, purified by precipitation treatments, with consequent cristallization of ammonium fluoroberyllate and emissions of water. Subsequently, the salt is heated resulting in the production of molten beryllium fluoride (BeF2) and emissions of NH4F gas. In the reduction phase, BeF2 is then mixed with molten magnesium to produce a mixture of beryllium pebbles (Be) and magnesium fluoride (MgF2). Refinement of the beryllium pebbles is conducted in a vacuum furnace. Finally, powder metallurgy, sintering, and hot pressing are used to produce beryllium metal. The reactions involved are the followings: ;Be(OH)2 + 2NH4HF2 --> (NH4)2BeF4 + 2H2O;(NH4)2BeF4 --> BeF2 + 2NH4F;Mg + BeF2 --> Be + MgF2;;;References: ;Nuss, P., & Eckelman, M. J. (2014). Life cycle assessment of metals: a scientific synthesis. PLoS One, 9(7), e101298.;;;Morana, S. J., & Simons, G. F. (1962). Beryllium extracted by the fluoride process. JOM, 14(8), 571-574.
processDocumentation.dataTreatmentDescription: Airborne emissions of beryllium nitrogen oxides and hydrogen fluoride were adapted considering the removal efficiency of specific emission control technologies (see comments to the exchanges). Sludge exchange was added to account for this removed waste and for the sake of mass balance.

exchanges.description:
Calculated value based on the distance covered for transporting beryllium hydroxide within the US borders. Specifically, beryllium hydroxide is transported from Topaz-Spor Mountain region (Utah) to the facility in Delta (Utah) over a distance of 85 km circa.

Reference:
Nuss, P., & Eckelman, M. J. (2014). Life cycle assessment of metals: a scientific synthesis. PloS one, 9(7), e101298.
USGS (2017). Minerals Yearbook - Beryllium.

exchanges.description:
The original value in the literature is 0.404 kg per kg of beryllium metal and semi-finished products produced. It is considered that NOx is removed by means of floating bed scrubber, with 95% efficiency. 

Reference: 
Jiuan, Y.L., 2005. Evaluation of wet scrubber systems. BSc Dissertation. University of Southern Queensland, Faculty of Engineering and Surveying

exchanges.description:
Literature. Conservative estimate as it represents the cumulative emissions estimate per kg beryllium produced at all operations (i.e., includes alloying and production of semi-finished shapes sold to end-users). The value is adapted to consider the use of airborne emission control system such as venturi scrubber, with a removal efficiency of 84.5% on average (USEPA, 2003. Air Pollution Control Technology
Fact Sheet- EPA-452/F-03-017)

exchanges.description: Calculated value for obtaining mass balance, based on dry mass = 0.1. This exchange is used as a proxy for the removed emissions of NOx, HF and Be. Indeed, it contains such emissions removed with scrubbers. See comments to emissions to air of Nitrogen oxides, Hydrogen fluoride, Beryllium for further explanation on the values in the mathematical relation.
